verses.text: All who are under the yoke as slaves must regard their own masters as worthy of full respect, so that the name of God and our teaching may not be blasphemed.
verses.comment: Paul urges Christian slaves to model respect, preserving the reputation of Christ and apostolic teaching. Early Christians were often accused of social disruption (see Titus 2:9-10).

verses.text: Those who have believing masters should not show less respect because they are brothers; instead, they must serve them all the more, since those who benefit from their service are believers, dearly loved. Teach and encourage these things.
verses.comment: Paul treats Christian social bonds as transformative; even within unjust systems, believers are urged to outdo one another in love. Bondservants should recognize the spiritual dignity even in servitude.

verses.text: If anyone teaches a different doctrine and does not agree with the sound words of our Lord Jesus Christ and with the teaching that accords with godliness,
verses.comment: Paul lays down the standard: true teaching is that of Christ and apostolic tradition. Sound doctrine preserves unity and holiness. See 2 Timothy 1:13 for the emphasis on holding fast the apostolic message.

verses.text: He is puffed up with conceit and understands nothing. He has an unhealthy craving for debates and quarrels over words, leading to envy, strife, slander, evil suspicions,
verses.comment: Paul describes the fruit of false teaching: division and pride. In contrast, genuine doctrine brings humility and unity. Titus 3:9 echoes this warning against unprofitable controversies.

verses.text: and constant friction among people of corrupt mind and deprived of truth, imagining that godliness is a means of gain.
verses.comment: The misuse of religion for personal profit is condemned—compare Simon Magus's error in Acts 8:18-23. The authentic Christian life rejects materialism and greed within spiritual leadership.

verses.text: But godliness with contentment is great gain.
verses.comment: True wealth lies in godliness and inner peace, not material accumulation. Christ teaches seeking God first brings all necessary provision (Matthew 6:33).

verses.text: For we brought nothing into the world, and we can take nothing out.
verses.comment: Echoes of Job 1:21 and Psalm 49:17 emphasize the fleeting nature of worldly possessions and the call to focus on eternal treasures and spiritual inheritance.

verses.text: But if we have food and clothing, with these we will be content.
verses.comment: A simple life, trusting God for essentials, is honored. Christ teaches contentment and freedom from worry (Matthew 6:25-32). Spiritual discipline forms the heart of Christian virtue.

verses.text: But those who desire to be rich fall into temptation, into a trap, into many foolish and harmful cravings, which plunge people into ruin and destruction.
verses.comment: Riches bring spiritual danger—see James 5:1-3. Material pursuit can wreck faith, whereas spiritual poverty is often transformative (see Proverbs 23:4-5).

verses.text: For the love of money is a root of all sorts of evil, and by craving it some have wandered away from the faith and pierced themselves with many sorrows.
verses.comment: Paul warns that disordered desire for wealth leads to apostasy and suffering. Compare Christ’s warning to the rich young ruler (Matthew 19:23-26).

verses.text: But you, O man of God, flee these things and pursue righteousness, godliness, faith, love, endurance, and gentleness.
verses.comment: Paul lists virtues that reflect the fruit of the Spirit (Galatians 5:22-23). Such traits express the life of grace and are cultivated by spiritual discipline and prayer.

verses.text: Fight the good fight of the faith. Take hold of the eternal life, to which you were called and for which you made the good confession in the presence of many witnesses.
verses.comment: Christian life is spiritual battle; Paul’s metaphor aligns with athletic contest (1 Corinthians 9:25-27). Public confession, perhaps in baptism, marks the spiritual journey begun in Christ.

verses.text: I charge you in the presence of God, who gives life to all, and of Christ Jesus, who testified the good confession before Pontius Pilate,
verses.comment: Paul refers to Christ’s bold witness before Pilate (John 18:37). The invocation of God as Creator implies the seriousness and universality of Timothy’s task.

verses.text: that you keep the commandment without stain or reproach until the appearing of our Lord Jesus Christ,
verses.comment: The return of Christ is a motivation for unwavering fidelity. “Commandment” may refer to the apostolic rule of faith, suggesting the need for lasting, visible obedience.

verses.text: which he will display at the proper time—the blessed and only Sovereign, the King of kings and Lord of lords,
verses.comment: This exalted title for Christ points to His unique authority and divinity. “King of kings and Lord of lords” connects to prophecy (Daniel 2:47 and Revelation 17:14), affirming Christ’s cosmic rule.

verses.text: who alone has immortality, who dwells in unapproachable light, whom no man has seen or can see. To him be honor and eternal dominion. Amen.
verses.comment: Christ, as God the Son, possesses life in Himself and dwells in the unseen glory. The reference to ‘unapproachable light’ alludes to God’s holiness in Psalm 104:2 and John 1:18.

verses.text: Instruct those who are rich in the present age not to be proud or to trust in uncertain riches, but to put their hope in God, who richly provides us with everything to enjoy.
verses.comment: Paul instructs the wealthy to humility and reliance on God’s Providence—a teaching echoed throughout the Old Testament. Enjoyment and generosity are sanctified when centered in God.

verses.text: They are to do good, to be rich in good works, to be generous, and ready to share,
verses.comment: Generosity is the mark of sanctified prosperity. Spiritual growth entails works of mercy, aligning with the call to love in tangible and sacrificial ways (Hebrews 13:16).

verses.text: thus storing up for themselves a treasure as a firm foundation for the future, so that they may take hold of that which is truly life.
verses.comment: Good works build heavenly treasures—see Matthew 6:19-20. Paul suggests earthly stewardship has eternal consequence, foreshadowing rewards revealed through union with Christ.

verses.text: O Timothy, guard what has been entrusted to you. Turn away from irreverent, empty chatter and the contradictions of what is falsely called 'knowledge',
verses.comment: ‘Deposit’ refers to the apostolic faith and doctrine—see 2 Timothy 1:14. Timothy is exhorted to preserve the received tradition against speculation and so-called wisdom.

verses.text: which some have professed and thus have wandered away from the faith. Grace be with you.
verses.comment: Paul ends with another warning about heresy leading to apostasy. The prayer for grace signals the primacy of God’s assistance in persevering in faith and truth. Also reflects the traditional closing blessing in 2 Corinthians 13:14.
